column6: Procurement of the Main Turbine Vibration System Probes - Tutuka PS
column9:
On 4 April 2023, an urgent situation arose at Tutuka Power Station. The
procurement department went out on enquiry for the procurement of the main
turbine vibration probes which are to be used on unit 6 that had to be returned
to service on the 19th of April but has since failed to and is on an outage slip.
While unit 6 was down its vibration probes were taken to unit 3 that needed
the probes urgently with the hope that procurement was going to place an
order and have the probes delivered in time. While the normal procurement
process was in the process Tutuka received communication from te OEM of
the probes that they had been phased out on the 1st of April 2023 and that
replacement probes will take 20 weeks from the date of order placement to be
delivered, an urgency then arose to the effect that unit 6 will not be able to be
returned to service without these vibration probes as they are very critical to the
operation of the main turbines. Without the probes the turbine cannot be put
on load and hence no electricity can be generated. It is of paramount
importance that these pumps are available if unit 6 is to return to service soon.
The station cannot afford to wait for 20 weeks as this will mean that the unit
won’t be available throughout the whole winter.

column9:

Centre (DEC). The situation arose as a result of the Data Energy Centre
Emergency Recovery Project that was declared by Transmission GE on the 15
March 2022. During investigation of the faulty systems and equipment it was

July 2022 as what was thought to be minor repairs of the fire detection

instruction was given to the expect the Fire System Inspection Authority (FSIB)
to carry

column6: Urgent Supply and Delivery of South Grade 1 (Catlight) - Duvha PS
column9:
On 2023/05/23 an urgent situation arose at Duvha Power Station (South units).
The situation arose as a result of: Fuel oil tank running low due to units
experiencing challenges with milling plant (Unit 1 and U2). Fuel oil is the daily
operational commodity that is required for compliance with the FFFR
Regulations during units light up and shutdown, mill changes, combustion
support on low loads and for emergencies (Unit capabilities, low coal bunker
levels due to coal shortages and wet coal, BFPT & EFP’s not available). low
coal bunker levels due to coal shortages and wet coal, BFPT & EFP’s not
available). The South fuel oil tank was depleted due to both units (Units 1 and
2) running on 3 mills since yesterday. The issue started when we received wet
coal, the units were supported with oil burners in order stabilise the
combustion and this has resultant on high fuel oil consumption. The situation
persisted to the point where we lost the two running units at South (units1 and
2). The above said challenges has depleted the South fuel oil tank to the
critical level where we will be challenged to return these two units and at the
state where the fuel oil pumps will suck sludge and causing the serious
damage to the other parts of the plant. In order to avert an undesirable
situation, extra fuel oil 10 loads were requested as per the daily activities from
the National contract (4600071904, 4600071906 and 4600071906) through the
Contract’s Manager, unfortunately our request could not be accommodated
due to high fuel oil usage through the generation fleet and due to restricted
number of daily loads allocation. For today the station was allocated 6 loads.
The urgent procurement process is to order extra fuel oil tankers outside the
fuel oil contract in order to augment the fuel oil tank. This will ensure that there
is sufficient fuel oil to return the two units.
